pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:0.4: 6. The training rule on asking for meat
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.2: At that time the nuns from the group of six ate meat after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.4: “How can nuns eat meat after asking for it?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.5: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t want tasty food?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.6: The nuns heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.7: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.8: “How can the nuns from the group of six eat meat after asking for it?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.9: “Is it true, monks, that those nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.12: How can the nuns from the group of six eat meat after asking for it?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.13: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.14: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.15: ‘If a nun asks for meat and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.16: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.1.17: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.1: Soon afterwards a number of nuns were sick.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.2: The nuns who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.4: “Previously we ate meat after asking for it, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.5: But now that this has been prohibited by the Buddha, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.7: “Monks, I allow a sick nun to eat meat after asking for it.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.8: And so, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.9: ‘If a nun who is not sick asks for meat and then eats it, she must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:1.2.10: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.6: one who is comfortable without meat.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.8: one who is not comfortable without meat.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.10: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.11: If she is not sick and she asks for her own benefit, then the effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.12: When she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.1.13: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.1: If she is not sick, and she does not perceive herself as sick, and she eats meat after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.2: If she is not sick, but she is unsure of it, and she eats meat after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.3: If she is not sick, but she perceives herself as sick, and she eats meat after asking for it, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.4: If she is sick, but she does not perceive herself as sick, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.5: If she is sick, but she is unsure if she is, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.2.6: If she is sick, and she perceives herself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.3: if she asked for it when she was sick, but eats it when she is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.4: if she eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.6: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.7: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.8: if it is by means of her own property;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.10: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pd6:2.3.11: The sixth training rule on acknowledgment is finished.
